title: Tired of being tired? Natural ways to get the energy you crave
intro: Do you feel like you're sleepwalking through the week? Instead of reaching for your third coffee of the day, consider tweaking your lifestyle habits. Gut health expert Dr. Amy Shah explains how small changes in your diet and sleep can help you naturally recharge. And to get that spring in your step again, experts share how to find something that lights you up from within.Follow us on Instagram: @nprlifekitSign up for our newsletter here.Have an episode idea or feedback you want to share? Email us at lifekit@npr.orgSupport the show and listen to it sponsor-free by signing up for Life Kit+ at plus.npr.org/lifekit

transcript.author: MARIELLE SEGARRA, HOST
transcript.text: You're listening to LIFE KIT...

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: ...From NPR.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Hey. It's Marielle. Is anybody else tired, like, a lot of the time?

transcript.author: AMY SHAH
transcript.text: That is something I hear on a daily basis. People complain in almost every age group that they are tired. It's like you feel exhausted all day, even if you've slept enough, even if you think you're doing all the right things.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Dr. Amy Shah is a double board-certified MD and a nutrition expert and author of the book "I'm So Effing Tired: A Proven Plan To Beat Burnout, Boost Your Energy, And Reclaim Your Life." As the title of the book suggests, Amy herself used to live in a near-constant state of exhaustion. She was a young doctor with a busy private practice and two kids at home when she noticed shifts in her mood and her body, like weight gain, irritability and trouble sleeping. But she couldn't pin down a specific cause for all of it. And when she turned to her doctor friends for advice...

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Everybody just said, you know, oh, of course you're tired. You're a mom with young kids. You're working full time. You're, you know, getting older. That was my favorite. I felt like there was something more, but I didn't know what. And it really felt kind of disappointing that nobody could help me and that this was just going to be life.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Then Amy got in a car crash. She'd been rushing from a busy day at work to pick up her kids from karate. Her car spun until she hit a divider in the middle of the road. It was totaled.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: That week that I had to take off to kind of pick up the pieces, I really started to change my life.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Amy was tired of always being tired, and she wasn't willing to accept fatigue as her new normal, so she started looking for answers and got really intentional about her nutrition and her daily schedule.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: And when I did change that, that's when I started to see the real results.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Results as in enough energy to hike to Machu Picchu. And get this. While there, a Peruvian tour guide told her they'd never seen anyone do the hike so effortlessly.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Now, we can't promise you that level of energy boost from this episode, but we will sure try. LIFE KIT reporter Andee Tagle is going to talk more with Amy about her gutsy approach to energy. And she'll also talk with a psychologist and an award-winning author and offer you some simple and surprising research-backed strategies on how to jump-start your energy.

transcript.author: ANDEE TAGLE, BYLINE
transcript.text: First up, body energy. OK, show of imaginary hands. How many of you are here because you're trying to kick your caffeine dependency?

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Your energy is like a bank. So if you drink coffee and you borrow from the bank, you have to pay it back later.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: We all know there are no magic pills out there, but maybe, like me, when you got to be on, you got to be on. So you often reach for quick Band-Aid boosters like caffeine or sugary snacks, or maybe even a combination of the two, all the livelong day because it feels like the only alternative is to try to function in zombie mode. The thing is, those habits, as in excessive caffeine and sugar consumption, can wreak havoc on your gut, which, in turn, can mess with your whole system. Amy says you might have some clues if that's already the case.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: One of the telltale signs is you're tired all the time, even if you've gotten a good night's sleep. Brain fogginess is another sign. So people will say, like, you know, I just can't think straight. A lot of people will feel inflammation in their joints.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: See, according to Amy, your gut is the center of an important ongoing conversation in your body.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: This, like, constant communication between the gut, the hormones and the immune system.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And when they're all in harmony, she says, energy follows.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Your gut health and hormone health are so intertwined that when you do improve your gut health, your immune health and your hormone health get better.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And to explain how that works, takeaway one - if you want more natural gusto, be good to your gut. Our guts influence our energy on multiple levels. In addition to managing digestion and the absorption of nutrients, our guts both produce and support our hormones. Like, did you know 95% of serotonin is produced there? When needed, our gut bacteria create inflammation to ward off invaders or disease, which can also slow you down. And the gut moves fast.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: These gut bacteria turn over really quick, and they can respond very quickly to what's happening in your outside world. And so if you change what you're eating and what you're doing for even three days, you're going to start to feel the beneficial effects of this.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: The beneficial effects of being good to your gut, that is. But what does that mean, exactly? Allow us to illustrate. Picture your gut like a food-processing factory. There are all these little bacteria workers lined up along the conveyor belt of your digestive tract to disassemble whatever you decide to eat. We'll start with your favorite cheesy bag of potato chips.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: What happens is that the gut microbes look at this and they say, well, there's - this does not look like food to me. I'm not really sure what it is. So it calls in immune cells to kind of help it kind of isolate it, take it out of our system.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: So for a lot of food additives - artificial colors, flavors, preservatives - it's like one of those little workers hits a button on the wall calling for a special security team. Red alert, red alert, intruder.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: That is called inflammation. And then, in turn, you will get an elevation of your cortisol, and you'll get signs to the brain to kind of slow down what it's doing so that we can concentrate on getting rid or categorizing this toxin.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Now let's turn to, say, a handful of blueberries. Your body is like...

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: I know what that is. Get that and, like, let's absorb the vitamins and send it through and produce some good feel-good chemicals because we just were able to eat the skin.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: So those blueberries help feed your gut to promote additional serotonin, which positively impacts our body's energy. And they also have anti-inflammatory properties. So when you need a snack and you grab that bag of potato chips over those blueberries, your body has to borrow resources, use a little extra battery life and brain power that might otherwise be fueling your daily decision-making and activities. Amy says think about it like a bad hangover.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Think of a day when you've had a lot of alcohol and the next day and how your gut feels and how your brain feels and how tired you feel. This happens on a micro level whenever we're eating junk foods or alcohol, et cetera.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Woof, am I right? If, like me, you are suddenly super motivated to turn things around, real, fibrous foods are where to start - so things like the aforementioned blueberries, avocados, leafy greens.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Seeds and nuts, cruciferous vegetables as well, like broccoli, cauliflower, brussels sprouts. These are foods that support that gut bacteria.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Also on the do list - food diversity, especially plant-based foods.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Try new vegetables, try new fruits, try new spices because that is something that will really improve your gut health, which will then, in turn, improve your energy.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: That doesn't mean you have to go out and blow a whole paycheck at the grocery store, though. There are a lot of budget-friendly foods that are also good for your gut - dried beans, canned peas and other legumes, for example. Also, the frozen section is your friend.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Frozen berries are often actually healthier than fresh berries because the frozen are often frozen at their peak of vitamins and freshness. And same with vegetables.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Moving towards what to moderate. Amy says you want to avoid processed meats and keep other meat consumption to a minimum - like, one serving a day and not more than five a week. A long-standing dietary guideline, by the way, is to keep saturated fats to less than 10% of your daily calories. So a lean, ideally organic chicken breast would be better than an all-beef burger. If you're big on dairy, she suggests sticking towards the fermented kind to help your gut, so yogurt, kefir, cottage cheese, feta.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: OK, top things to avoid - No. 1, no surprise here, processed and ultra-processed foods. You're probably eating more of it than you think. Fried and high-preservative foods, as well as what Amy called one of the worst offenders to your energy levels, sugar-sweetened beverages, like soda or fruit punch. Because, she says, you're often getting hit on multiple fronts - sugar, caffeine levels, other food additives.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: So your blood sugar spikes and then drops. And then your cortisol spikes when your blood sugar spikes. And then your inflammation levels rise. And all of that happens so fast because it's a drink.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Yikes. Anyone else totally sold but also a little overwhelmed? Luckily, Amy's got another quick idea to jolt the system. This one's a lighter lift but still packs a punch. Takeaway two - supercharge your circadian rhythm.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: One of the biggest energy boosts that has become a nonnegotiable for me is getting some sunlight in the morning.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: So easy, right? You've heard this a million times, yes? But how often do you actually do it? Consider this your sign to start. For real, all you need is a couple of minutes, ideally within an hour of waking up. And look; we're not talking tropical vacation levels of sunshine. It can be overcast. It can be rainy.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: It just means that you have natural light reaching your eyes. And from your retina, there's a direct connection to your suprachiasmatic nucleus in your brain that is in the hormonal centers.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: That's like your body's master clock. It sets a bunch of things in motion.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: And it's so interesting because that gut bacteria that lives all the way in your lower colon also loves sunlight. They also send signals to your brain that they're happy and you get more energized and focused. So that is one of the easiest ways to boost energy that has nothing to do with changing the way you eat.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: But we're just getting started with our clocks. Our next power play is something Amy calls circadian fasting. Don't let the terminology scare you.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: A hundred years ago, it was not called circadian fasting. It was just called life. But now that we live in this 24/7 world, we have to actually stop eating at a certain time so that our bodies can rest and digest and then give it a break.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Because when you don't give your digestive system adequate recovery time, you can't expect it to be able to perform at its best.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Almost like if someone woke you up in the middle of the night and asked you to do, like, a complicated math problem. You'd probably not do it very well. And the next day, you would probably be tired and mad that you had to.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Our gut bacteria need a chance to be off the clock, kick off their shoes. Like, consider how you feel at the end of an average eight-hour work shift. Amy says our guts are accustomed to processing our food for 12-hour shifts at a time. But the data shows we Americans are typically eating for...

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: Fifteen, 16 hours a day and only leaving a break for about 8 hours.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And that often leads to poor health outcomes. Research has shown people who eat large meals very late at night have increased rates of insulin resistance, GI problems like acid reflux and, you guessed it, often feel tired, especially in the morning. So if you want to be good to your gut and good to your body clock at the same time, you might consider taking deliberate, scheduled, consistent breaks from eating. One such way to do that - Amy's idea of circadian fasting.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: As the name suggests, it's a style of eating that simply tries to sync up with your natural circadian rhythms. So you want to fast overnight, aiming to eat in the light hours and fast in the dark. That isn't, like, a hard-and-fast rule. You don't have to rush through dinner if the sun is setting. The idea is just to give your gut as much time as possible to digest.

transcript.author: SHAH
transcript.text: So you might eat dinner at 6 or 7 p.m. and then wake up at 6 or 7 and then maybe not have your first meal until 8 or 9.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: In her book, Amy advises keeping three things constant. First, observe at least a 12-hour fast window. Second, you want to keep that window as close to your circadian clock as possible. Finally, stop eating three hours before you go to sleep. Of course, with all of this, you want to check in with your doctor first if you have any questions or concerns, and you want to keep checking in with your body to see how those schedule changes have affected your sleep, your mood and your energy.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: All right, how are we feeling? All sounds simple enough, but maybe easier said than done? Agreed. After the break, let's work on that mental battery and get you pumped.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: All right. Next up, let's talk emotional energy. To make changes, we first have to figure out where you're channeling your energy and what might be sapping you. Of course, that list might be long. There are systemic factors that impact all of us to different degrees, many of which we have little or no control over. And carrying that awareness around - that you can't just prevent all the bad stuff from happening - can be heavy and scary.

transcript.author: ENMANUEL MERCEDES
transcript.text: But I think what it also does is, like, if we're able to recognize that awareness with a sense of acceptance and move into the idea of what is available for me to do? Not what do I want the ideal situation to be like, but instead is, what is available for me to do under the circumstances, under this situation, under this reality?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And that's takeaway three - assess your emotional energy bill and recharge on a daily basis because...

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: Oftentimes when we think about energy, we're thinking about how to boost energy as opposed to how do we preserve energy.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: This is Enmanuel Mercedes, Manny (ph), a counseling psychologist in private practice in New Jersey. He's also a very proud father to three boys.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: Ages 10, 5 and 3, so you can imagine the amount of energy that is required (laughter).

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Manny says no matter your current stage or situation in life - new grad trying to find your way in the world, working father of three, grandparent eager to reach retirement - our cultural norm is to push for more, do the most, spread ourselves as thin as possible.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: The expectations are so high, and so when we try to do everything and we fail at it, not only do we find ourselves physically exhausted, but emotionally, psychologically just depleted.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And he says we can really start to get into trouble when we burn all our fuel on things that we don't really care about or that don't actually serve us.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: How much of our energy is spent stressing out, ruminating, thinking about problems that may not be within our scope of being able to resolve, right?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: A 2025 Gallup survey found that Americans who live in ways aligned with their core values are more likely to be thriving than those who do not. And like, yeah, duh, right? But get this. Many widely practiced daily behaviors, namely frequent social media use, news consumption, the use of AI and nonessential shopping, are far less likely to align with what we say matters most to us. And that gap between our values and our daily habits was closely tied to lower life satisfaction and to optimism. That took some air out of my tires pretty quick. The point - if you want an emotional boost, find alignment.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: To start, here at LIFE KIT, we love a time audit. You could try logging just today or logging a week. Just take stock of how you're actually spending your energy, not just the highlights, as in...

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: What is happening around me? And what is my reaction or my response to things that are happening around me?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Then add up and categorize your time - an hour chatting with friends, three hours of podcast, 10 hours commuting, 12 hours on social media - that can't be right. Then from your list, take stock of what feels good and what feels bad. Maybe break out some markers and do some color coding if you're feeling wild. Then try going one step further.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: What are the things that I actually have influence or control over versus the things that are completely out of my control?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: The answer to that question can give you the agency to best recalibrate your schedule according to your values. Like, maybe you realize your TV watching block is a lot bigger than you'd like it to be, and your exercise block is a lot smaller. Maybe you realize you're always in a bad mood after interacting with that one person in the family. Some things will have a quick fix, and others will remain immovable. But Manny says just practicing some awareness around the energy vampires in your life can help take away their power.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: I simply lean back and like, OK, I'm going to let them finish whatever statement they have. I'm not engaging. If this is something that I need to deal with, let me just deal with it and move forward in my life, as opposed to spending all this energy and all this effort into things that don't necessarily provide you a return on your energy investment.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: From there, a final calendar mandate from Manny that I love - remember to charge your emotional battery every day.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: I love the idea of, like, oh, you know what? I'm going to go to the spa and then I'm going to get a massage. But the thing is, that's the equivalent of practicing once a month a skill, and then thinking, why am I not getting any better?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: This one hit like a ton of bricks because it's so simple but so often overlooked. And yes, this is me talking to me.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: 'Cause every day you're dealing with stress. Every day that you're dealing with stress also means that every day you need to have a recovery process.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: You plug in your phone or your laptop most every night, no? Or if you forget, you're not surprised when it dies in the middle of the day. Our operating systems are way more complex than any computer, so mind all those tabs open in your head, and build in that personal emotional battery booster. That could look like a meditation or breathing practice, some morning yoga.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: It may have something to do with actual physical activity, like working out, strength training or running.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And let's quickly note, if you're doing all of these things - practicing healthy habits, managing your stress - and you still can't seem to find energy, Manny says it might be time to consult a care provider.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: Something about that indicates that there's either a medical, physical condition that needs to be explored, or there may be a psychiatric or mental illness condition that may need to be considered.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: In any case, Manny says protecting your peace in a way that's true to your values - never a bad idea.

transcript.author: MERCEDES
transcript.text: I would call it the ultimate energy hack, is to live present and intentionally, and finding ways to then create a routine that actually sustains the outcome that we want - something that we practice on a daily basis.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Our last guest is here to help us cultivate an energetic spirit, and she fully agrees with Manny. Her novel approach to living in the present - try surfing.

transcript.author: KAREN WALROND
transcript.text: Oh, my gosh, I'm doing it. Like, the guide's, like, sort of cheering you - go, go, go, go, go - right? Like, that is a really, really exhilarating feeling.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Karen Walrond is an author, a speaker, a leadership coach and this episode's designated energy ambassador. She brings us takeaway four - curiosity is critical. Explore more, and don't be scared to be an amateur. Her most recent book is titled "In Defense Of Dabbling: The Brilliance Of Being A Total Amateur." For Karen, being an amateur is a wonderful thing.

transcript.author: WALROND
transcript.text: The etymology of the word, it means one who loves. And I was like, well, why aren't we more proud of being an amateur, and not only that, seek out amateur pursuits, when we're living in a world that could definitely use more people who love, right?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Case in point, those surf lessons we were just talking about.

transcript.author: WALROND
transcript.text: And I had never experienced - like, I'd body surfed before, you know, like, playing in the waves. But it's a totally different experience to be on the board when that wave takes you. Like, it literally feels like you're almost on a little speedboat.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Surfing was right on the edge of Karen's comfort zone. She loves the ocean, but the task itself was a bit intimidating. It took a lot of physical exertion just to paddle out, and then she was pulled under a wave a bit on her first go. So when she finally popped up on that board, oh, the energy.

transcript.author: WALROND
transcript.text: That delight, that little shot of exhilaration, like, that's kind of what you're going for, right? Like, it's - all of a sudden you're delighting in yourself. And there's so few opportunities in the world where you get to delight in yourself.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Karen says what started out for her as a book about hobbies led her to much deeper lessons about how to connect to herself, about finding vitality. And it's made her a real evangelist for the regular practice of trying out new interests - classes, pastimes, places - simply for their own pleasure and for the energy that brings.

transcript.author: WALROND
transcript.text: I really think there's a reason it's called recreation - like re-creation. It literally is about how do you get back to who you are without the overwhelm, without the worry that goes out?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: A good hobby can bring play into your life or lead you to an invigorating flow state. It can connect you to other people in the real world or just to a sense of wonder and awe. Of course, not everyone can or cares to learn to surf specifically, but Karen says the regular practice of amateurism - be it coding or Hula-Hooping or painting or pottery or a different one of those every week - can pay out in dividends just because you can say you've been there.

transcript.author: WALROND
transcript.text: The energizing thing was also talking about it with my partner afterwards. The energizing is talking about it with you as I sort of relive that thing that happened in - you know, over a year ago at this point. Like, the energizing thing, it - that lasts.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And finding that kind of energy in your day-to-day life - the kind you get from the childlike joy of discovery or exploration or growth when you try something new, even in super small ways - it's worth the effort.

transcript.author: WALROND
transcript.text: I think when you're a kid, you're constantly delighting yourself or learning something new. But as you get older, that becomes less and less frequent, I think. And I really - I believe that that idea of chasing that delight in yourself, like, that's how we live well. That's how we age well. Like, that, to me, is the secret sauce of living.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: OK, let's have one quick high-energy recap. Takeaway one - to give your body a boost, be good to your gut. Fibrous food and cruciferous vegetables are the name of the game. Takeaway two - supercharge your circadian rhythm. Get that morning sunlight in and give your digestive system a break every day. Takeaway three - assess your emotional energy bill and build in a stress relief practice daily. And Takeaway four - curiosity is critical. Explore more, and don't be scared to be an amateur.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: That was LIFE KIT reporter Andee Tagle.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Hey, before we go, I have a favor to ask. If you have a second, would you leave LIFE KIT a five-star review? If LIFE KIT has ever helped you save a little money, make a healthier choice or if we've just made you feel a little more seen, a five-star review is a great way to show your support. And thank you.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: This episode of LIFE KIT was produced by Margaret Cirino. Our visuals editor is Beck Harlan, and our digital editor is Malaka Gharib. Meghan Keane is our senior supervising editor, and Beth Donovan is our executive producer. Our production team also includes Clare Marie Schneider, Sylvie Douglis and Mika Ellison. Engineering support comes from Stacey Abbott. Fact-checking by Tyler Jones. I'm Marielle Segarra. Thanks for listening.

lines: You're listening to LIFE KIT...
...From NPR.
Hey. It's Marielle. Is anybody else tired, like, a lot of the time?

That is something I hear on a daily basis. People complain in almost every age group that they are tired. It's like you feel exhausted all day, even if you've slept enough, even if you think you're doing all the right things.

Dr. Amy Shah is a double board-certified MD and a nutrition expert and author of the book "I'm So Effing Tired: A Proven Plan To Beat Burnout, Boost Your Energy, And Reclaim Your Life." As the title of the book suggests, Amy herself used to live in a near-constant state of exhaustion. She was a young doctor with a busy private practice and two kids at home when she noticed shifts in her mood and her body, like weight gain, irritability and trouble sleeping. But she couldn't pin down a specific cause for all of it. And when she turned to her doctor friends for advice...

Everybody just said, you know, oh, of course you're tired. You're a mom with young kids. You're working full time. You're, you know, getting older. That was my favorite. I felt like there was something more, but I didn't know what. And it really felt kind of disappointing that nobody could help me and that this was just going to be life.
Then Amy got in a car crash. She'd been rushing from a busy day at work to pick up her kids from karate. Her car spun until she hit a divider in the middle of the road. It was totaled.
That week that I had to take off to kind of pick up the pieces, I really started to change my life.

Amy was tired of always being tired, and she wasn't willing to accept fatigue as her new normal, so she started looking for answers and got really intentional about her nutrition and her daily schedule.
And when I did change that, that's when I started to see the real results.
Results as in enough energy to hike to Machu Picchu. And get this. While there, a Peruvian tour guide told her they'd never seen anyone do the hike so effortlessly.

Now, we can't promise you that level of energy boost from this episode, but we will sure try. LIFE KIT reporter Andee Tagle is going to talk more with Amy about her gutsy approach to energy. And she'll also talk with a psychologist and an award-winning author and offer you some simple and surprising research-backed strategies on how to jump-start your energy.
First up, body energy. OK, show of imaginary hands. How many of you are here because you're trying to kick your caffeine dependency?
Your energy is like a bank. So if you drink coffee and you borrow from the bank, you have to pay it back later.

We all know there are no magic pills out there, but maybe, like me, when you got to be on, you got to be on. So you often reach for quick Band-Aid boosters like caffeine or sugary snacks, or maybe even a combination of the two, all the livelong day because it feels like the only alternative is to try to function in zombie mode. The thing is, those habits, as in excessive caffeine and sugar consumption, can wreak havoc on your gut, which, in turn, can mess with your whole system. Amy says you might have some clues if that's already the case.

One of the telltale signs is you're tired all the time, even if you've gotten a good night's sleep. Brain fogginess is another sign. So people will say, like, you know, I just can't think straight. A lot of people will feel inflammation in their joints.
See, according to Amy, your gut is the center of an important ongoing conversation in your body.
This, like, constant communication between the gut, the hormones and the immune system.
And when they're all in harmony, she says, energy follows.
Your gut health and hormone health are so intertwined that when you do improve your gut health, your immune health and your hormone health get better.

And to explain how that works, takeaway one - if you want more natural gusto, be good to your gut. Our guts influence our energy on multiple levels. In addition to managing digestion and the absorption of nutrients, our guts both produce and support our hormones. Like, did you know 95% of serotonin is produced there? When needed, our gut bacteria create inflammation to ward off invaders or disease, which can also slow you down. And the gut moves fast.

These gut bacteria turn over really quick, and they can respond very quickly to what's happening in your outside world. And so if you change what you're eating and what you're doing for even three days, you're going to start to feel the beneficial effects of this.

The beneficial effects of being good to your gut, that is. But what does that mean, exactly? Allow us to illustrate. Picture your gut like a food-processing factory. There are all these little bacteria workers lined up along the conveyor belt of your digestive tract to disassemble whatever you decide to eat. We'll start with your favorite cheesy bag of potato chips.

What happens is that the gut microbes look at this and they say, well, there's - this does not look like food to me. I'm not really sure what it is. So it calls in immune cells to kind of help it kind of isolate it, take it out of our system.

So for a lot of food additives - artificial colors, flavors, preservatives - it's like one of those little workers hits a button on the wall calling for a special security team. Red alert, red alert, intruder.

That is called inflammation. And then, in turn, you will get an elevation of your cortisol, and you'll get signs to the brain to kind of slow down what it's doing so that we can concentrate on getting rid or categorizing this toxin.
Now let's turn to, say, a handful of blueberries. Your body is like...
I know what that is. Get that and, like, let's absorb the vitamins and send it through and produce some good feel-good chemicals because we just were able to eat the skin.

So those blueberries help feed your gut to promote additional serotonin, which positively impacts our body's energy. And they also have anti-inflammatory properties. So when you need a snack and you grab that bag of potato chips over those blueberries, your body has to borrow resources, use a little extra battery life and brain power that might otherwise be fueling your daily decision-making and activities. Amy says think about it like a bad hangover.

Think of a day when you've had a lot of alcohol and the next day and how your gut feels and how your brain feels and how tired you feel. This happens on a micro level whenever we're eating junk foods or alcohol, et cetera.
Woof, am I right? If, like me, you are suddenly super motivated to turn things around, real, fibrous foods are where to start - so things like the aforementioned blueberries, avocados, leafy greens.
Seeds and nuts, cruciferous vegetables as well, like broccoli, cauliflower, brussels sprouts. These are foods that support that gut bacteria.
Also on the do list - food diversity, especially plant-based foods.
Try new vegetables, try new fruits, try new spices because that is something that will really improve your gut health, which will then, in turn, improve your energy.

That doesn't mean you have to go out and blow a whole paycheck at the grocery store, though. There are a lot of budget-friendly foods that are also good for your gut - dried beans, canned peas and other legumes, for example. Also, the frozen section is your friend.
Frozen berries are often actually healthier than fresh berries because the frozen are often frozen at their peak of vitamins and freshness. And same with vegetables.

Moving towards what to moderate. Amy says you want to avoid processed meats and keep other meat consumption to a minimum - like, one serving a day and not more than five a week. A long-standing dietary guideline, by the way, is to keep saturated fats to less than 10% of your daily calories. So a lean, ideally organic chicken breast would be better than an all-beef burger. If you're big on dairy, she suggests sticking towards the fermented kind to help your gut, so yogurt, kefir, cottage cheese, feta.

OK, top things to avoid - No. 1, no surprise here, processed and ultra-processed foods. You're probably eating more of it than you think. Fried and high-preservative foods, as well as what Amy called one of the worst offenders to your energy levels, sugar-sweetened beverages, like soda or fruit punch. Because, she says, you're often getting hit on multiple fronts - sugar, caffeine levels, other food additives.
So your blood sugar spikes and then drops. And then your cortisol spikes when your blood sugar spikes. And then your inflammation levels rise. And all of that happens so fast because it's a drink.

Yikes. Anyone else totally sold but also a little overwhelmed? Luckily, Amy's got another quick idea to jolt the system. This one's a lighter lift but still packs a punch. Takeaway two - supercharge your circadian rhythm.
One of the biggest energy boosts that has become a nonnegotiable for me is getting some sunlight in the morning.

So easy, right? You've heard this a million times, yes? But how often do you actually do it? Consider this your sign to start. For real, all you need is a couple of minutes, ideally within an hour of waking up. And look; we're not talking tropical vacation levels of sunshine. It can be overcast. It can be rainy.
It just means that you have natural light reaching your eyes. And from your retina, there's a direct connection to your suprachiasmatic nucleus in your brain that is in the hormonal centers.
That's like your body's master clock. It sets a bunch of things in motion.

And it's so interesting because that gut bacteria that lives all the way in your lower colon also loves sunlight. They also send signals to your brain that they're happy and you get more energized and focused. So that is one of the easiest ways to boost energy that has nothing to do with changing the way you eat.
But we're just getting started with our clocks. Our next power play is something Amy calls circadian fasting. Don't let the terminology scare you.

A hundred years ago, it was not called circadian fasting. It was just called life. But now that we live in this 24/7 world, we have to actually stop eating at a certain time so that our bodies can rest and digest and then give it a break.
Because when you don't give your digestive system adequate recovery time, you can't expect it to be able to perform at its best.

Almost like if someone woke you up in the middle of the night and asked you to do, like, a complicated math problem. You'd probably not do it very well. And the next day, you would probably be tired and mad that you had to.

Our gut bacteria need a chance to be off the clock, kick off their shoes. Like, consider how you feel at the end of an average eight-hour work shift. Amy says our guts are accustomed to processing our food for 12-hour shifts at a time. But the data shows we Americans are typically eating for...
Fifteen, 16 hours a day and only leaving a break for about 8 hours.

And that often leads to poor health outcomes. Research has shown people who eat large meals very late at night have increased rates of insulin resistance, GI problems like acid reflux and, you guessed it, often feel tired, especially in the morning. So if you want to be good to your gut and good to your body clock at the same time, you might consider taking deliberate, scheduled, consistent breaks from eating. One such way to do that - Amy's idea of circadian fasting.

As the name suggests, it's a style of eating that simply tries to sync up with your natural circadian rhythms. So you want to fast overnight, aiming to eat in the light hours and fast in the dark. That isn't, like, a hard-and-fast rule. You don't have to rush through dinner if the sun is setting. The idea is just to give your gut as much time as possible to digest.
So you might eat dinner at 6 or 7 p.m. and then wake up at 6 or 7 and then maybe not have your first meal until 8 or 9.

In her book, Amy advises keeping three things constant. First, observe at least a 12-hour fast window. Second, you want to keep that window as close to your circadian clock as possible. Finally, stop eating three hours before you go to sleep. Of course, with all of this, you want to check in with your doctor first if you have any questions or concerns, and you want to keep checking in with your body to see how those schedule changes have affected your sleep, your mood and your energy.
All right, how are we feeling? All sounds simple enough, but maybe easier said than done? Agreed. After the break, let's work on that mental battery and get you pumped.

All right. Next up, let's talk emotional energy. To make changes, we first have to figure out where you're channeling your energy and what might be sapping you. Of course, that list might be long. There are systemic factors that impact all of us to different degrees, many of which we have little or no control over. And carrying that awareness around - that you can't just prevent all the bad stuff from happening - can be heavy and scary.

But I think what it also does is, like, if we're able to recognize that awareness with a sense of acceptance and move into the idea of what is available for me to do? Not what do I want the ideal situation to be like, but instead is, what is available for me to do under the circumstances, under this situation, under this reality?
And that's takeaway three - assess your emotional energy bill and recharge on a daily basis because...
Oftentimes when we think about energy, we're thinking about how to boost energy as opposed to how do we preserve energy.
This is Enmanuel Mercedes, Manny (ph), a counseling psychologist in private practice in New Jersey. He's also a very proud father to three boys.
Ages 10, 5 and 3, so you can imagine the amount of energy that is required (laughter).

Manny says no matter your current stage or situation in life - new grad trying to find your way in the world, working father of three, grandparent eager to reach retirement - our cultural norm is to push for more, do the most, spread ourselves as thin as possible.
The expectations are so high, and so when we try to do everything and we fail at it, not only do we find ourselves physically exhausted, but emotionally, psychologically just depleted.
And he says we can really start to get into trouble when we burn all our fuel on things that we don't really care about or that don't actually serve us.
How much of our energy is spent stressing out, ruminating, thinking about problems that may not be within our scope of being able to resolve, right?

A 2025 Gallup survey found that Americans who live in ways aligned with their core values are more likely to be thriving than those who do not. And like, yeah, duh, right? But get this. Many widely practiced daily behaviors, namely frequent social media use, news consumption, the use of AI and nonessential shopping, are far less likely to align with what we say matters most to us. And that gap between our values and our daily habits was closely tied to lower life satisfaction and to optimism. That took some air out of my tires pretty quick. The point - if you want an emotional boost, find alignment.
To start, here at LIFE KIT, we love a time audit. You could try logging just today or logging a week. Just take stock of how you're actually spending your energy, not just the highlights, as in...
What is happening around me? And what is my reaction or my response to things that are happening around me?

Then add up and categorize your time - an hour chatting with friends, three hours of podcast, 10 hours commuting, 12 hours on social media - that can't be right. Then from your list, take stock of what feels good and what feels bad. Maybe break out some markers and do some color coding if you're feeling wild. Then try going one step further.
What are the things that I actually have influence or control over versus the things that are completely out of my control?

The answer to that question can give you the agency to best recalibrate your schedule according to your values. Like, maybe you realize your TV watching block is a lot bigger than you'd like it to be, and your exercise block is a lot smaller. Maybe you realize you're always in a bad mood after interacting with that one person in the family. Some things will have a quick fix, and others will remain immovable. But Manny says just practicing some awareness around the energy vampires in your life can help take away their power.

I simply lean back and like, OK, I'm going to let them finish whatever statement they have. I'm not engaging. If this is something that I need to deal with, let me just deal with it and move forward in my life, as opposed to spending all this energy and all this effort into things that don't necessarily provide you a return on your energy investment.
From there, a final calendar mandate from Manny that I love - remember to charge your emotional battery every day.

I love the idea of, like, oh, you know what? I'm going to go to the spa and then I'm going to get a massage. But the thing is, that's the equivalent of practicing once a month a skill, and then thinking, why am I not getting any better?
This one hit like a ton of bricks because it's so simple but so often overlooked. And yes, this is me talking to me.
'Cause every day you're dealing with stress. Every day that you're dealing with stress also means that every day you need to have a recovery process.

You plug in your phone or your laptop most every night, no? Or if you forget, you're not surprised when it dies in the middle of the day. Our operating systems are way more complex than any computer, so mind all those tabs open in your head, and build in that personal emotional battery booster. That could look like a meditation or breathing practice, some morning yoga.
It may have something to do with actual physical activity, like working out, strength training or running.

And let's quickly note, if you're doing all of these things - practicing healthy habits, managing your stress - and you still can't seem to find energy, Manny says it might be time to consult a care provider.
Something about that indicates that there's either a medical, physical condition that needs to be explored, or there may be a psychiatric or mental illness condition that may need to be considered.
In any case, Manny says protecting your peace in a way that's true to your values - never a bad idea.

I would call it the ultimate energy hack, is to live present and intentionally, and finding ways to then create a routine that actually sustains the outcome that we want - something that we practice on a daily basis.
Our last guest is here to help us cultivate an energetic spirit, and she fully agrees with Manny. Her novel approach to living in the present - try surfing.
Oh, my gosh, I'm doing it. Like, the guide's, like, sort of cheering you - go, go, go, go, go - right? Like, that is a really, really exhilarating feeling.

Karen Walrond is an author, a speaker, a leadership coach and this episode's designated energy ambassador. She brings us takeaway four - curiosity is critical. Explore more, and don't be scared to be an amateur. Her most recent book is titled "In Defense Of Dabbling: The Brilliance Of Being A Total Amateur." For Karen, being an amateur is a wonderful thing.

The etymology of the word, it means one who loves. And I was like, well, why aren't we more proud of being an amateur, and not only that, seek out amateur pursuits, when we're living in a world that could definitely use more people who love, right?
Case in point, those surf lessons we were just talking about.

And I had never experienced - like, I'd body surfed before, you know, like, playing in the waves. But it's a totally different experience to be on the board when that wave takes you. Like, it literally feels like you're almost on a little speedboat.

Surfing was right on the edge of Karen's comfort zone. She loves the ocean, but the task itself was a bit intimidating. It took a lot of physical exertion just to paddle out, and then she was pulled under a wave a bit on her first go. So when she finally popped up on that board, oh, the energy.

That delight, that little shot of exhilaration, like, that's kind of what you're going for, right? Like, it's - all of a sudden you're delighting in yourself. And there's so few opportunities in the world where you get to delight in yourself.

Karen says what started out for her as a book about hobbies led her to much deeper lessons about how to connect to herself, about finding vitality. And it's made her a real evangelist for the regular practice of trying out new interests - classes, pastimes, places - simply for their own pleasure and for the energy that brings.
I really think there's a reason it's called recreation - like re-creation. It literally is about how do you get back to who you are without the overwhelm, without the worry that goes out?

A good hobby can bring play into your life or lead you to an invigorating flow state. It can connect you to other people in the real world or just to a sense of wonder and awe. Of course, not everyone can or cares to learn to surf specifically, but Karen says the regular practice of amateurism - be it coding or Hula-Hooping or painting or pottery or a different one of those every week - can pay out in dividends just because you can say you've been there.

The energizing thing was also talking about it with my partner afterwards. The energizing is talking about it with you as I sort of relive that thing that happened in - you know, over a year ago at this point. Like, the energizing thing, it - that lasts.

And finding that kind of energy in your day-to-day life - the kind you get from the childlike joy of discovery or exploration or growth when you try something new, even in super small ways - it's worth the effort.

I think when you're a kid, you're constantly delighting yourself or learning something new. But as you get older, that becomes less and less frequent, I think. And I really - I believe that that idea of chasing that delight in yourself, like, that's how we live well. That's how we age well. Like, that, to me, is the secret sauce of living.

OK, let's have one quick high-energy recap. Takeaway one - to give your body a boost, be good to your gut. Fibrous food and cruciferous vegetables are the name of the game. Takeaway two - supercharge your circadian rhythm. Get that morning sunlight in and give your digestive system a break every day. Takeaway three - assess your emotional energy bill and build in a stress relief practice daily. And Takeaway four - curiosity is critical. Explore more, and don't be scared to be an amateur.
